newsitem.title: ZAIRE: Zaire refugee town under curfew after rebel thrust.
newsitem.headline: Zaire refugee town under curfew after rebel thrust.

text.p: The town of Bukavu in east Zaire, tense in the face of a Tutsi rebel advance, spent a second night under curfew after Zairean troops pulled back from positions to the south in confusion.

"We are waiting for something. We do not know what it is or why it is happening," a visibly frightened school teacher said in the South Kivu capital, where up to 300,000 uprooted Hutu refugees from Rwanda and Burundi have headed seeking refuge.
Earlier, anxious Zairean soldiers set up roadblocks in case of attack. Shops were closed for a second straight day.
In Brussels, Zairean Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo accused troops from Rwanda's Tutsi-dominated army of entering Zaire to back their kinsmen among the Banyamulenge rebels.
"Rwanda must withdraw from Zaire. Zaire will defend its rights with all means at its disposition," Kengo said.
Zaire has appealed to the U.N. Security Council over what it terms "external aggression" in its eastern region.
Rwanda and Burundi have denied any link with the fighting.
Zaire, sprawling and chaotic, has been a powder keg since Hutu-Tutsi hatred spilled across its borders in 1994.
Over a million Hutus arrived from Rwanda fearing reprisals after Hutu hardliners massacred minority Tutsis there that year. Other Hutus have fled from civil war with Tutsis in Burundi.
Fighting between Zairean troops and the Banyamulenge flared on Friday around Uvira near the border with Burundi. More than 200,000 Hutu refugees in camps in the area took flight.
Aid workers reported dozens of people killed.
The Banyamulenge, who migrated from Rwanda late in the 18th century, accuse Zaireans of trying to force them to leave.
A Banyamulenge spokesman in Rwanda said they had joined forces with Zairean groups of Kaasai, Shaba and Katangese and captured three eastern towns -- Kamanyola, Nyangezi and Bwegera.
The Kaasai, Shaba and Katangese have led armed opposition to President Mobutu Sese Seko off and on since the 1960s.
The spokesman said all the 300,000 Banyamulenge wanted was the return of property stolen by troops and militiamen and the granting of Zairean citizenship, denied to them in 1981.
Aid groups earlier expressed fears of lack of food for the flood of refugees descending on Bukavu and its outskirts.
Refugees arriving in their thousands were being directed towards a camp at Nyamarengwe, about 20 km (12 miles) to the southwest.
Some appeared to be carrying provisions. Many had harrowing tales of their five days on the move.
"There were women giving birth on the road. There were old men and women collapsing with exhaustion," Georges Nzohikera, a Hutu from Burundi, said.
